Hi Colin,

I think it's pretty reasonable to speculate that some initial =
"primed" connectivity is specified through DNA that then goes through chang=
es according to rules of plasticity.  Of course, there is probably not a st=
rict "pre-specified" period and another strict "plastic" period, because in=
 reality they likely overlap from the very start, but the general idea that=
 both elements are present and that the pendulum swings gradually away from=
 pre-specification makes sense to me.  From a neuroevolution perspective, i=
t's possible to imagine variants of adaptive HyperNEAT that exhibit more or=
 less of this type of dynamic.  Adaptive HyperNEAT was described in "Indire=
ctly Encoding Neural Plasticity as a Pattern of Local Rules," which is at h=
ttp://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications/2010/risi.sab10.html .  Of course we ar=
e continuing to explore these types of plastic models.

About the junk DNA =
hypothesis - it's the type of thing you can't really definitively verify as=
 true or false, but if some initial "randomness" in the brain was provided =
by junk DNA it wouldn't be that surprising.  But the thing I kind of object=
 to in the quotations you provided is the idea that this idea is "bold."  I=
t doesn't seem to me to be a major problem to explain how disorganized rand=
onmness can get into a system.  I mean, random initialization (which is a s=
tandard part of many EAs and other learning algorithms) is generally not th=
e interesting part, at least not in terms of being the part that requires g=
reat intellectual effort to conceive or understand.  So if nature in fact t=
ook one arbitrary route to getting a little randomness into things over ano=
ther, it doesn't seem that impressive or fortuitous compared to how it disc=
overed the parts that are, in contrast, well-organized.  

ken
